Event 1: Initial Consultation (February 5, 2023)  
The patient first presented to Dr.  Emily Harper with complaints of severe and persistent 
abdominal pain. Dr. Harper, without performing any diagnostic tests, diagnosed the patient 
with gastritis and prescribed a course of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs). No further 
investigations, such as bl ood tests or imaging, were recommended. This was the first opportunity to identify the underlying issue, which later proved to be a 
large abdominal mass. Event 2: Persistent Symptoms and Referral (February 28, 2023)  
John Doe returned to the clinic on February 28, 2023, with no improvement in symptoms.

The patient underwent surgery to remove the mass on May 2, 2023. During the procedure, it 
was noted that the sterile equipment used was mishandled, leading to post -operative 
infection. This infection caused a delayed recovery and significantly impacted the  patient’s 
health. Improper use of antibiotics and delays in responding to the infection also contributed 
to the deterioration of the patient’s condition. Event 6: Development of Sepsis and ICU Admission (May 15, 2023)  
On May 15, 2023, the patient developed sepsis and was admitted to the ICU. The infection, 
which originated from improper sterilization during surgery, caused a systemic response, 
leading to the need for critical care. The patient was treated with IV antibi otics and eventually 
stabilized, but the delay in diagnosis and treatment significantly impacted his overall health 
and quality of life. 4. Breach of Duty  
Multiple breaches of duty occurred in this case:  
• Failure to Properly Investigate:  During the initial consultation, Dr. Harper failed to 
perform necessary diagnostic tests, missing the opportunity for early detection. • Delay in Imaging:  The scheduling and execution of the abdominal ultrasound were 
delayed due to administrative and communication errors, further postponing the 
diagnosis.

Despite the worsening of his abdominal pain, Dr. Harper referred the patient for an 
ultrasound, scheduled nearly three weeks later. This delay, coupled with the absence of 
immediate imaging or blood work, contributed to the worsening of the condition. Event 3: Ultrasound Delays (March 15, 2023)
